title: 108_s1538
content: The Act may be cited as the "DSHEA Full Implementation and Enforcement Act of 2003". Congress finds that over 158 million Americans use dietary supplements to improve their health, with consumer spending reaching $17.1 billion in 2000. The FDA predicts continued growth in supplement use due to factors like aging populations and advancements in science. The DSHEA was enacted in 1994 to regulate dietary supplements. DSHEA, enacted in 1994, ensures truthful and substantiated claims on dietary supplement labels. It sets standards for manufacturing practices and requires safety information for new ingredients. The FDA has updated its system for reporting adverse events related to dietary supplements. DSHEA provides authorities to remove unsafe supplements from the market and created the Office of Dietary Supplements for research and consumer information. The FDA has not effectively enforced DSHEA and requires more resources for implementation. The FDA has received additional funds beyond the President's budget to enforce DSHEA, reaching $9,700,000 in fiscal year 2003. However, the FDA states that full implementation of DSHEA would require between $24,000,000 and $65,000,000 per year. SEC. 3. AUTHORIZATION AND APPROPRIATION OF RESOURCES. Authorization of appropriations for the Dietary Supplement Health and Education Act of 1994 and regulatory requirements under the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act for fiscal years 2004 to 2008: $20,000,000 for 2004, $30,000,000 for 2005, $40,000,000 for 2006, $50,000,000 for 2007, and $65,000,000 for 2008. The Dietary Supplement Health and Education Act of 1994 authorizes appropriations for regulatory requirements on dietary supplements under the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act. $30,000,000 is allocated for expanded research and development of consumer information on dietary supplements for fiscal year 2004, with additional funding for subsequent years. The Food and Drug Administration is mandated to regulate dietary supplements using the allocated funds. SEC. 4. ANNUAL ACCOUNTABILITY REPORT ON THE REGULATION OF DIETARY SUPPLEMENTS. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must submit an annual report to Congress on the implementation and enforcement of the Dietary Supplement Health and Education Act of 1994. The report includes details on funding and personnel dedicated to dietary supplement regulation and adverse event reporting systems within the Food and Drug Administration. The annual report to Congress includes details on funding and personnel dedicated to enforcement of dietary supplement labeling, good manufacturing practices inspections, new ingredient reviews, safety reviews, and enforcement actions taken by the Food and Drug Administration. The annual report to Congress includes information on enforcement actions by the Food and Drug Administration and the Department of Health and Human Services related to dietary supplements, requests for substantiation of claims, determination of false claims, research and consumer education activities supported by the Office of Dietary Supplements, and any recommendations for administrative or legislative actions. The annual report to Congress includes information on enforcement actions related to dietary supplements, requests for substantiation of claims, determination of false claims, research, and consumer education activities. Recommendations for administrative or legislative actions regarding dietary supplements are also included. Any additional information deemed appropriate by the Secretary of Health and Human Services or the Commissioner of Food and Drugs is also provided.
